text:
We run a TOAM analysis (see image below) to determine what all they could rank for, grouped by buckets (we use our cluster algorithm to do the grouping), and then sorted by opportunity (balance of value/difficulty).

Knowing the revenue potential of the available market then enables us to begin calculating what it's going to cost to begin capturing portions of it from the incumbents. 

So from there it's a matter of plugging in some basic numbers for costs (e.g. content + links/promotion). 

If you don’t know you're exact numbers, that's okay. We use Fermi decomposition to make reasonable estimations when lacking hard data—and it works well.

If we want to get more granular with link costs, then we go deeper and do what we call a link intelligence report (see below). 

I'm writing up and article about how we approach a TOAM over the weekend. I'm share once I do. You might be able to get some insight from it to begin calculating it.

text: We calculate those and then basically say, "Here's the math. How much money do you want to make? If they tell us that, we can run Monte Carlo simulations to build financial projections with upper/lower bounds for ROI. We like to use Causal to plot that data.

elements.text: We calculate those and then basically say, "Here's the math. How much money do you want to make? If they tell us that, we can run Monte Carlo simulations to build financial projections with upper/lower bounds for ROI. We like to use Causal to plot that data.

text:
I'd been thinking about creating a product/service where we write a pillar cluster series for clients. The idea is 6 cluster posts and one pillar for $ X. I was having lunch with a great client (software developer) yesterday and after we talked about it a bit, he asked for a proposal.

Now I'm wondering...
1. Can I demonstrate results in 60 days?
2. Is this kind of one off approach, using pillar/cluster a good way to sell clients on an ongoing content marketing agreement?
3. Any software or software developer marketers out there willing to offer insight on this?

elements.text:
I'd been thinking about creating a product/service where we write a pillar cluster series for clients. The idea is 6 cluster posts and one pillar for $ X. I was having lunch with a great client (software developer) yesterday and after we talked about it a bit, he asked for a proposal.

Now I'm wondering...
Can I demonstrate results in 60 days?
Is this kind of one off approach, using pillar/cluster a good way to sell clients on an ongoing content marketing agreement?
Any software or software developer marketers out there willing to offer insight on this?

attachments.text: Getting your site architecture right is one of the harder parts of building a site, whether you’re dealing with millions of pages or hundreds. These patterns will help you understand the best way to create yours.

text: Me! I’m on a small content team (me + 2 other writers), so we collaborated heavily on the details. It was a 2-week sprint process that includes team estimation and a simple kanban-style sprint board. Unfortunately, it didn’t work well because the rest of the marketing team was on a different schedule, and they had a hard time understanding/respecting the content team’s sprint timing. So we would get interrupted/redirected a lot, which made stories carry over from sprint to sprint, which was demoralizing. If I were doing it over again, I would protect my team’s time more aggressively. I also could have done a better job advocating for our sprint approach in the first place. I still think content sprints are an awesome idea and want to try again in the future.
